title: The NADH Dehydrogenase Nde1 Executes Cell Death after Integrating Signals from Metabolism and Proteostasis on the Mitochondrial Surface
abstract: Highlights d A fraction of the mitochondrial NADH dehydrogenase Nde1 is exposed to the cytosol d Nde1 is degraded by the proteasome but accumulates in respiration-deficient cells d Cytosol-exposed Nde1 generates a toxic fragment that triggers apoptosis d Nde1-mediated cell death prevents the propagation of respiratory compromised cells

abstract.text: Highlights d A fraction of the mitochondrial NADH dehydrogenase Nde1 is exposed to the cytosol d Nde1 is degraded by the proteasome but accumulates in respiration-deficient cells d Cytosol-exposed Nde1 generates a toxic fragment that triggers apoptosis d Nde1-mediated cell death prevents the propagation of respiratory compromised cells

body_text.text: Mitochondria are essential organelles of eukaryotic cells. Even in simple organisms, such as baker's yeast, mitochondria contain many hundreds of different polypeptides, which differ strongly in abundance (Morgenstern et al., 2017) . Whereas some mitochondrial proteins are present at several hundred thousand copies per cell, other proteins are present at only a few copies. The abundance of mitochondrial proteins also responds dynamically to physiological needs and differs strongly between respiring and fermenting conditions.

Protein abundance is determined by the rates of protein expression and biogenesis on the one hand and by protein stability and degradation on the other, with both processes being tightly regulated (Ghaemmaghami et al., 2003; McShane et al., 2016; Schwanh€ ausser et al., 2011; Wheatley et al., 1980) . The processes that regulate and coordinate the synthesis, import, and assembly of mitochondrial proteins are well understood (Couvillion et al., 2016; Forsburg and Guarente, 1989; Neupert, 2016; Poyton and McEwen, 1996) . In comparison, our knowledge of the proteolytic systems that determine the lifetime of mitochondrial proteins remains very limited.

The control of general protein abundance by degradation is particularly important during phases of cellular acclimation where extensive proteome remodeling is observed. In addition, under unperturbed conditions, proteolytic systems have been shown to be relevant for the removal of dysfunctional, unassembled, or mistargeted mitochondrial proteins (Mohanraj et al., 2019; Quiró s et al., 2015) . Furthermore, cells can employ protein turnover as regulatory mechanisms, for example in the mitophagy-controlling PINK1-Parkin system (Fang et al., 2019; Jin et al., 2010; Lazarou et al., 2015; Sekine et al., 2019) . However, the extent to which protein turnover is important for regulating protein abundance under unperturbed, steady-state conditions is much less clear. Particularly, little is known about the degradation of mitochondrial proteins that have already reached a functional state. Many proteome-wide studies were based on GFP fusion proteins, which makes the data unreliable and difficult to interpret, because the fused GFP moiety compromises the sorting and functionality of many proteins (Belle et al., 2006; Weill et al., 2018; Yen et al., 2008) . We therefore aimed to identify mitochondrial proteins with high turnover rates by using a minimally invasive pulse-labeling approach based on stable isotopelabeled amino acids and mass spectrometry (Doherty et al., 2009; Zhang et al., 2014) .

This approach revealed a homogeneous turnover for most mitochondrial proteins. Nonetheless, we observed that the NADH dehydrogenase Nde1 is turned over at a much higher rate than most other mitochondrial proteins. Unexpectedly, we observed that Nde1 exists in two topologically distinct forms.

One form serves as an NADH dehydrogenase while the other functions as a signaling factor to trigger regulated cell death in yeast. Our observations suggest that this signaling factor is part of a mechanism that monitors the cellular status of both metabolism and proteostasis and integrates these signals to eliminate respiratory deficient cells from yeast populations.

Mass spectrometry in combination with isotope labeling of proteins (e.g., stable isotope labeling by amino acids in cell culture [SILAC] ) has become the gold standard for global and accurate quantification of protein abundance (Ong et al., 2002) . Variations in the labeling strategy allow the adaptation of this well-established proteomics methodology to address specialized questions. We employed a dynamic SILAC procedure to screen for mitochondrial proteins with exceptionally high turnover rates. Yeast cells were grown in medium with ''light'' amino acid isotopes, reisolated, and switched to ''heavy'' [ 13 C 6 / 15 N 4 ] arginine and [ 13 C 6 / 15 N 2 ] lysine-containing medium. At different time points, aliquots were taken from this logarithmically growing culture, mitochondria were isolated, and proteins were analyzed by mass spectrometry ( Figure 1A ). Over time, heavy peptides replaced the light ones, thereby allowing us to rank mitochondrial proteins according to their relative turnover rates. In total, we detected 290 mitochondrial proteins, of which 148 were quantified in at least 4 of the 7 time points. The incorporation rates of heavy amino acids showed a very narrow distribution across the analyzed proteins ( Figures 1B-1D ). After approximately one and two doubling times, the percentage of heavy (A) Schematic representation of the dynamic SILAC labeling approach. (B) Peptides with heavy amino acids increase over time. The heavy-to-total ratios for all detected peptides were plotted for different time points after switching to the heavy medium. If all proteins were infinitely stable, 50% and 75% of heavy peptides would be expected after 1 and 2 doubling times, respectively. The measured ratios are very close to these values. (C) The fractions of heavy peptides for each mitochondrial protein were plotted over time. Nde1 and Qcr10 showed a much higher turnover than any other mitochondrial protein. (D) Ratio of heavy over light peptides for each mitochondrial protein 4.5 h after switching to heavy medium. Means and SDs from n = 5 biological replicates are shown.
body_text.section: Dynamic Isotope Labeling Identifies Nde1 as a Mitochondrial Protein with Exceptionally High Turnover Rate

body_text.text: peptides increased on average to 47.1% and 72.5% with SDs of 4.1% and 5.2%, respectively. This almost perfectly matches the values of 50% and 75% that would be expected if protein degradation rates are negligible in comparison to protein synthesis rates in the exponentially growing culture investigated here. Therefore, our results suggest that most mitochondrial proteins have a high stability. However, there were some notable exceptions, the most pronounced of which were Nde1 and Qcr10, which turned over considerably faster than other mitochondrial proteins ( Figure 1C ). This finding was consistent across five independent replicates of the experiment ( Figure 1D ). In summary, we find that mitochondrial proteins are generally very stable in exponentially growing cell cultures albeit with some notable exceptions.
body_text.section: Dynamic Isotope Labeling Identifies Nde1 as a Mitochondrial Protein with Exceptionally High Turnover Rate

body_text.text: The rapid degradation of Nde1 was not observed for its close homologs Nde2 and Ndi1. This indicates that the high turnover rate is not simply an unavoidable consequence of an intricate or unstable structure ( Figures 1C and 1D ). Nde1, Nde2, and Ndi1 are all NADH dehydrogenases that transfer electrons from NADH to ubiquinone. They are functional equivalents of complex I of the respiratory chain, although they do not pump protons. Nde1 and Nde2 contain stop-anchor sequences and are tethered via N-terminal transmembrane domains to the intermembrane space (IMS) side of the inner membrane, while Ndi1 faces the matrix side ( Figure 2A ). They are, at least in part, functionally redundant, because all the single deletion mutants Dnde1, Dnde2, and Dndi1, are able to grow on non-fermentable carbon sources ( Figure 2B ). Mitochondria isolated from these strains can also still use NADH as a substrate for oxidative phosphorylation, as determined by in vitro oxygen consumption assays ( Figure 2C ). Considerable defects in oxygen consumption were, however, observed in a Dnde1 Dnde2 double deletion mutant.
body_text.section: Nde1 Affects Cellular Fitness Independently of Its NADH Dehydrogenase Function

body_text.text: Because the absence of Nde1 did not considerably affect respiration rates, it is unlikely that the high turnover of Nde1 constitutes a regulatory switch of mitochondrial NADH dehydrogenase activity. We therefore asked whether there might be a second role of Nde1, which requires its rapid turnover. To test for the consequences of increased Nde1 levels, we replaced the endogenous genomic Nde1 promoter with a strong regulatable GAL10 promoter. Using an Nde1-specific antibody, we confirmed the overexpression of Nde1 in this strain upon growth in the presence of galactose ( Figure S1A ), and this Nde1 overexpression was accompanied with a strongly reduced cell number (Figures 2D and 2E) . Surprisingly, the toxic phenotype was independent of the NADH dehydrogenase function, because the overexpression of Nde1 containing mutations in the NADH binding pocket in the Rossmann fold (Scrutton et al., 1990 ) still prevented cell growth ( Figures 2F, 2G , S1B-S1E). This toxicity was also independent of respiration, because it was also observed in cells grown anaerobically ( Figure 2F ). In summary, we conclude that Nde1 exhibits two distinct functions, one as an electron transfer enzyme in the respiratory chain and one that is detrimental for yeast cell viability. The high turnover of Nde1 is apparently related to the latter function. The indicated strains were grown to log phase in glucose medium. Ten-fold serial dilutions were dropped on the plates that contained the indicated carbon sources. (C) 100 mg of mitochondria isolated from indicated strains were incubated in a Clark electrode and oxygen consumption was measured after addition of 7 mM NADH. (D) Cellular extracts of the indicated strains were analyzed by western blotting using antibodies raised against Nde1, Ilv5, and Sod1. (E) The indicated strains were precultured on glucose medium before their growth was analyzed. (F) Nde1 wild-type or mutant versions were expressed from a GAL promoter in wild-type cells. Growth was analyzed in the presence or absence of oxygen. (G) Oxygen consumption after NADH addition was measured with mitochondria isolated from the indicated strains. The residual dehydrogenase activity in the Dnde1 mitochondria is due to the presence of Nde2 in these strains. Means and SDs from n = 4 independent technical replicates are shown.
body_text.section: Nde1 Affects Cellular Fitness Independently of Its NADH Dehydrogenase Function

body_text.text: Previous studies showed that both Nde1 and Nde2 accept NADH from the IMS site of the inner membrane (Luttik et al., 1998) . However, biochemical localization studies on Nde1 have not been performed before. We therefore assessed the cellular localization of an Nde1 version that was C-terminally tagged with GFP. Using fluorescence microscopy, we found this fusion protein to colocalized with mitochondria ( Figure 3A) . When mitochondria were purified from the Nde1-GFP-expressing strain, a protein with an apparent mass of $80 kDa was detectable with GFP-specific antibodies ( Figure 3B ), consistent with the combined size of Nde1 (58 kDa) and GFP (25 kDa). Interestingly, when these mitochondria were treated with proteinase K, Nde1-GFP signal was no longer detectable by western blot, while other IMS proteins remained proteinase-inaccessible. These results indicate that the GFP-domain was not completely (A) Nde1-GFP is a mitochondrial protein that colocalizes with mitochondria-targeted Su9-RFP (Mito-RFP). (B) Mitochondria were isolated from Nde1expressing cells, pretreated without or with 100 mg of proteinase K, lysed in sample buffer, and analyzed by western blotting with the indicated antibodies. OM, outer membrane. (C) Like (B), however, wild-type mitochondria were used and Nde1 was detected with an Nde1specific antibody. The position of the Nde1 fragment is indicated by an arrow (f N20 ). (D) Isolated wild-type mitochondria were incubated with the membrane-impermeable reagent sulfo-NHS-SS-biotin for 0, 10, or 30 min. The reagent was quenched. Mitochondria were lysed and either directly loaded to the gel (I, input, 10% of the total) or separated into fractions that were biotinylated (B) or non-biotinylated (NB, 10% loaded) to streptavidin beads. IM, inner membrane. (E) Model of the two Nde1 topomers found in wildtype mitochondria. translocated across the outer membrane but remained protease accessible on the mitochondrial surface ( Figure 3B ).
body_text.section: Nde1 Acquires Two Different Topologies in Mitochondria

body_text.text: Next, we assessed the topology of the endogenous Nde1 protein in wild-type cells. Upon addition of proteinase K, a considerable fraction of Nde1 was degraded, giving rise to a proteaseresistant fragment of $20 kDa (f N20 , Figure 3C) . This species was reproducibly observed with different yeast strains and growth conditions, even though the levels of the protease-accessible Nde1 species varied to some degree (Figure S2A ). The f N20 fragment was also detected after protease treatment of mitochondria expressing the Nde1-GFP fusion protein (Figure S2B) , indicating that this fragment comprises the N terminus of Nde1. When we added low concentrations of proteinase K to isolated mitochondria, a fraction of the full-length form was progressively degraded, resulting in intermediate-size fragments ( Figure S2C ). These fragments disappeared at high proteinase K concentrations where only full-length Nde1 and the f N20 fragment were observed ( Figures S2C and S2D ). Thus, Nde1 clearly exhibits different behavior compared to other IMS proteins such as Mia40 and Cox17, which are inaccessible to proteinase K.
body_text.section: Nde1 Acquires Two Different Topologies in Mitochondria

body_text.text: In order to confirm this unconventional topology, we used a biotinylation procedure, which exclusively modifies surfaceexposed proteins. This strategy was specifically developed to assess membrane protein topologies (Mammen et al., 1997) . After covalently crosslinking amino groups that are exposed to the surface of isolated mitochondria with sulfo-NHS-SS-biotin, the reagent was quenched, and mitochondria were lysed.
body_text.section: Nde1 Acquires Two Different Topologies in Mitochondria

body_text.text: Biotinylated and non-biotinylated proteins were separated using streptavidin-coated beads. As shown in Figure 3D , the cytosol exposed, mitochondrial outer membrane protein, Om14, was efficiently recovered with the streptavidin beads whereas proteins of the IMS, the inner membrane, and the matrix, were not. However, consistent with our protease assays, we observed that a considerable fraction of Nde1 was biotinylated, indicating that this species of Nde1 was accessible to the cytosol. Taken together, these results demonstrate that endogenous Nde1 has two distinct topomers ( Figure 3E ). In addition to the IMSlocated Nde1, there is a cytosol-exposed Nde1 fraction that appears to span both membranes. Both Nde1 topomers are processed by the matrix processing peptidase, thus we propose that the cytosol-exposed topomer remains associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane. However, we cannot formally exclude that after its processing by the matrix processing peptidase, a fraction of Nde1 slides back and is inserted into the outer membrane in a mode similar to that which was recently described for Om45 (Song et al., 2014; Wenz et al., 2014) . It seems likely that only the IMS-located Nde1 is enzymatically active and able to transfer electrons from NADH to ubiquinone, which resides in the inner membrane. The cytosol-exposed . body_text.section: Nde1 Acquires Two Different Topologies in Mitochondria

body_text.text: The Two Topomers of Nde1 Are Generated during Its Import into Mitochondria In order to better understand how the two different topomers of Nde1 are formed, we performed in vitro import experiments with isolated mitochondria and radiolabeled Nde1. During incubation, the precursor form of Nde1 gave rise to two species, one being protease-resistant to proteinase K ( Figure 4A , Mature), the other being converted to a specific fragment of $39 kDa that was absent without protease treatment ( Figures 4A and 4B, f 39 ) . Such a fragment was not seen with control proteins such as the inner membrane protein Oxa1 ( Figure S3A ). The Nde1 fragment was not the result of cleavage by the IMS protease Yme1, which is able to degrade import intermediates (Leonhard et al., 2000; Wu et al., 2018) , because the protected mature form and the proteinase K fragment also were observed when Nde1 was imported into Dyme1 mitochondria ( Figure S3B ).
body_text.section: Nde1 Acquires Two Different Topologies in Mitochondria

body_text.text: These import experiments suggest that a fraction of Nde1 precursor is not completely imported but instead gives rise to a protein species that exposes its C terminus to the outside of mitochondria. We consider it unlikely that this form represents an import intermediate, because the amount of this protease fragment was not diminished during longer import times (Figure 4A) . It is possible that folding of the C-terminal region in the precursor can counteract full translocation, a mechanism that was shown before to cause dual localization of the mitochondrial protein fumarase (Knox et al., 1998) . We observed that biogenesis of the fully protease-protected Nde1 species required a strong mitochondrial membrane potential ( Figure 4B ). When we added low amounts of the membrane uncoupler carbonyl cyanide m-chlorophenyl hydrazine (CCCP) to the import reaction, Nde1 did not reach a protease-resistant conformation. In contrast, the f N20 fragment was generated efficiently, indicating that the surface-exposed topomer of Nde1 is strongly enriched in poorly energized mitochondria ( Figure 4C) .
body_text.section: Nde1 Acquires Two Different Topologies in Mitochondria

body_text.text: In summary, we conclude that the two different topomers of Nde1 are generated during import into mitochondria. A fraction of Nde1 never fully translocates across the outer membrane, particularly when the mitochondrial membrane potential is low.
body_text.section: Nde1 Acquires Two Different Topologies in Mitochondria

body_text.text: To analyze the relevance of the specific targeting sequence of Nde1 in more detail, we overexpressed versions of Nde1 in which the targeting sequence was replaced by that of the IMSprotein Mia40 or that of the outer membrane protein Tom70 (Figures 4D, S3C, and S3D) . Interestingly, the Mia40-Nde1 protein still showed the same dual topology as Nde1 and was catalytically active, however, it was not toxic. In contrast, the Tom70-Nde1 protein was toxic but was unable to pass electrons from NADH to the respiratory chain ( Figures 4E and 4F ). Apparently, toxicity of Nde1 overexpression coincided with the generation of the 40 kDa fragment. This fragment was even formed when Nde1 was fused to the matrix-targeting cytochrome b D19 presequence, potentially owing to a translational arrest of a fraction of the protein ( Figures S3E and S3F ). Expression of the C-terminal NADH dehydrogenase domain of Nde1 without any mitochondrial targeting sequence was not toxic, because it was very rapidly degraded ( Figures S3E and S3F ). In line with this observation, C-terminal truncation of Nde1 annihilated its toxicity and resulted in a corresponding shortening of the fragment. In particular, the region between amino acids 430 and 500 seems to be crucial for toxicity (Figures S3G and S3H) .
body_text.section: Nde1 Acquires Two Different Topologies in Mitochondria

body_text.text: The high turnover of Nde1 suggests that at least one of the two Nde1 topomers is degraded by proteases in vivo. We also observed that in whole cell extracts, but not in isolated mitochondria, several Nde1-derived fragments are detected (Figure 5A ), suggesting that the cytosol-exposed topomer is preferentially degraded. Several recent studies have identified two major proteolytic systems that control the levels of IMS and outer membrane proteins, namely the Cdc48/proteasome system in the cytosol and the i-AAA protease Yme1 in the IMS (Jin et al., 2010; Kowalski et al., 2018; Leonhard et al., 1996; Må rtensson et al., 2019; Rampello and Glynn, 2017; Steffen et al., 2017; Vö gtle et al., 2011; Wrobel et al., 2015; Wu et al., 2018; Xu et al., 2011; Zö ller et al., 2018) . We employed a stability assay in which we monitored cellular Nde1 levels after inhibition of protein synthesis by cycloheximide ( Figure 5B ). This assay confirmed the proteolytic instability of Nde1. However, Nde1 was markedly stabilized when the proteasome inhibitor MG132 was added. In temperature-sensitive cdc48-2 cells, Nde1 was stabilized and Nde1-derived fragments accumulated, in particular at the restrictive temperature of 37 C ( Figures 5C, S4A , and S4B). Obviously, Cdc48 facilitates the degradation of the characteristic Nde1 fragment (f cyto , Figures 5C and S4B ). Expression of non-toxic Mia40-Nde1 fusion in the cdc48-2 strain did not lead to the accumulation of this fragment ( Figure 5D ). This fragment was present in cytosolic fractions and could be largely separated from mitochondria on sucrose gradients ( Figure 5E ). We conclude that the generation of a specific C-terminal fragment and its release from the mitochondria is responsible for the toxicity of Nde1.
body_text.section: Two Proteolytic Systems Cooperate in Nde1 Degradation

body_text.text: In order to better characterize components that are relevant for Nde1-dependent toxicity, we crossed a GAL-Nde1 overexpression allele into yeast libraries in which non-essential genes were systematically deleted and the expression of essential genes was compromised (Breslow et al., 2008; Giaever et al., 2002) . We reasoned that strains lacking components that favor the production of the toxic Nde1 fragment should show an increased resistance to Nde1 overexpression. Intriguingly, we found that mutants that affect the function of the proteasome are particularly resistant against Nde1-mediated toxicity. Moreover, many components of the mitochondrial import machinery were found to be critical for Nde1-mediated toxicity, particularly those of the import motor and the TIM22 complex ( Figure S5 ; Table S1). On the contrary, the deletion of the Cdc48 adaptor Doa1 that was previously shown to be relevant for degradation of mitochondrial proteins (Wu et al., 2016) did not provide resistance but rather strongly increased the levels of the toxic Nde1 fragment (Figures 5F and 5G). In cells lacking the mitochondrial i-AAA protease Yme1, an additional fragment accumulated that presumably represents the mitochondrial stub of the processed Nde1 ( Figures 5H and 5I ). Thus, mitochondrial (Yme1) and cytosolic (proteasome/Cdc48/Doa1) proteases cooperate in the degradation of the cytosol-exposed Nde1 topomer.
body_text.section: Two Proteolytic Systems Cooperate in Nde1 Degradation

body_text.text: Why is the cytosol-exposed Nde1 topomer toxic? We ruled out a respiration-related cause, because this topomer of Nde1 cannot transfer electrons to ubiquinone, and as observed earlier, both the wild-type version and catalytically inactive mutants of Nde1 are toxic upon overexpression. Nde1 belongs to a family of NADH dehydrogenases ( Figure 6A ; Table S2 ), which also includes the evolutionary conserved apoptosis inducing factor 1, Aif1 (Wissing et al., 2004) . Homologs of Aif1 are present in animals and humans, where they were reported to play an ill-defined role in apoptosis (Hangen et al., 2015; Joza et al., 2009; Susin et al., 1999) . In order to test whether Nde1 participates in programmed cell death, we treated wild-type and Dnde1 cells with the apoptosis-inducing reagents acetic acid and hydrogen peroxide (Ludovico et al., 2001; Madeo et al., 1999) for 3 h before we washed the cells and tested how many cells had survived the treatment ( Figures 6B and 6C ). While most of the Nde1-containing cells were dead after this treatment, the absence of Nde1 made cells largely insensitive to these apoptotic stimuli. Overexpression of Nde1, on the other hand, rendered cells even more susceptible to both chemical stressors ( Figures 6C, 6D , S6A, and S6B).
body_text.section: Nde1-Mediated Cell Death Shows Hallmarks of Apoptosis and Is Caused by a Fragment Derived from the Cytosol-Exposed Nde1 Topomer

body_text.section: Nde1-Mediated Cell Death Shows Hallmarks of Apoptosis and Is Caused by a Fragment Derived from the Cytosol-Exposed Nde1 Topomer

body_text.text: showed enhanced externalization of phosphatidylserine, a classical hallmark of this form of programmed cell death, compared to the insensitive Dnde1 strain (Madeo et al., 1997; Madeo et al., 1999) . Upon acetic acid treatment, Dnde1 cultures have considerably lower fractions of propidium iodide (PI)-positive cells (Figure 6E) , which confirms the insensitivity to this apoptotic stimulus. Subsequent annexin V/PI co-staining revealed that most of the PI-positive cells are also annexin V-positive and therefore late apoptotic cells (Carmona-Gutierrez et al., 2018; Madeo et al., 1997) . Thus, the presence of Nde1 is obviously involved in the induction of apoptosis in these cultures (Figures 6F and S6C) that coincides with oxidative stress in these cells ( Figure S6D ).

We noticed that during the treatment with acetic acid or hydrogen peroxide, levels of Nde1 increased considerably (Figure 6G) . Moreover, while levels of Nde1 declined over time after the addition of cycloheximide, they remained stable after the combined addition of cycloheximide and acetic acid ( Figure 6H ). This indicates that specific metabolic conditions prevent degradation of Nde1 and its toxic fragment that leads to cell death ( Figure 6I ).

The potential of Nde1 to induce cell death is influenced by its topology as well as by its proteolytic cleavage by mitochondrial and cytosolic proteases. Because we saw that its topology is influenced by membrane potential, we hypothesized that the energetic status of mitochondria might be of relevance for the propensity of Nde1 to act as an apoptotic factor. Indeed, upon Nde1 overexpression, we observed a strong accumulation of the cytosolic Nde1-derived fragment in cells that are unable to respire (f cyto , Figure 7A ). This fragment was not observed in wild-type cells, presumably owing to the more efficient Nde1 translocation across the outer membrane in healthy cells. In line with this, respiration-deficient cells, lacking the respiratory chain component Cox4, were more susceptible to mild apoptotic stimulation with acetic acid than wild-type cells. This phenotype, however, required the presence of Nde1 ( Figures 7B and S7A ). Furthermore, mutants of respiratory chain subunits were found much less frequently among the survivors in our screen for Nde1-resistant strains than expected by random sampling ( Figure S5 ). This suggests that Nde1-mediated apoptosis is used to counterselect against respiration-deficient cells. In fact, we observed an increased number of respiration-deficient (petite) colonies in glucose-grown Dnde1 cultures ( Figure 7C ), which were unable to grow on glycerol-containing medium ( Figure S7B ). These petite colonies characterize cells that harbor no or a non-functional mitochondrial genome (collectively termed rho 0 ) ( Figures 7D,  S7C , and S7D). Accordingly, when we incubated rho 0 mitochon-dria with radiolabeled Nde1 precursor, only very low amounts of Nde1 were completely translocated across the outer membrane, and most Nde1 accumulated in the surface-exposed topomer that was converted into the f N20 fragment upon protease addition (f N20 , Figure S7E) . In summary, we conclude that respirationdeficient mitochondria accumulate the cytosol-exposed Nde1 species that primes these cells to undergo apoptosis.
body_text.section: Induced Nde1 Fragment Formation Counteracts the Progression of Respiratory-Deficient Cells

body_text.text: Apoptosis is essential for the growth and development of multicellular eukaryotes. Why apoptotic cell death pathways also exist in unicellular organisms such as yeast is less clear. It was proposed that programmed cell death in microorganisms might eliminate the majority of cells under starvation conditions in order to spare a small number of young and robust survivors (B€ uttner et al., 2006) . The components that execute cell death pathways are apparently highly conserved, and many of the factors that trigger apoptosis in yeast also are central for cell death regulation in mammalian cells, such as a caspase (Madeo et al., 2002) , endonuclease G (B€ uttner et al., 2007) , a BH3 only protein (B€ uttner et al., 2011) , or apoptosis-inducing factor (Wissing et al., 2004) .

Our study shows that an Nde1-dependent cell death program counteracts the propagation of respiration-deficient mutants in yeast cultures. In yeast, as well as in animal cells, respirationdeficient strains can have higher growth rates under fermentative conditions, a phenomenon that was initially described by Cori and Cori (1925) and Warburg et al. (1927) . We observed that cultures lacking Nde1 accumulate cells that have lost their mitochondrial genome, whereas the presence of Nde1 apparently eliminates these cells. Thus, Nde1 seems particularly toxic for old and respiration-deficient cells. Apparently, Nde1-mediated apoptosis is used to maintain healthy populations of cells and provides a clear example of the relevance and importance of apoptosis to unicellular organisms.

Here, we show that the mitochondrial protein Nde1 can acquire two different topologies, one being active as an NADH dehydrogenase in cellular respiration, the other involved in the induction of cell death. The latter topomer exposes a large C-terminal domain to the cytosol. It is hence an ideal candidate to integrate information about the cellular status from the cytosol as well as from mitochondrial subcompartments. Replacement of the N-terminal region of Nde1 by the matrix-directing cytochrome b 2 D19 presequence still induces cell death, consistent with previous studies that reported that overexpression of matrix-localized Ndi1 can be lethal (Cui et al., 2012; Li et al., 2006) . We were able to separate the two activities of Nde1: an outer membrane-targeted Tom70-Nde1 protein was catalytically inactive but induces cell death, whereas a Mia40-Nde1 fusion (E and F) Cells were grown to exponential phase. Cells equivalent to OD 1 were then stressed in 100 mM acetic acid for 1 h (E) or 30 min (F). Cells were isolated, stained, and washed, and the number of stained cells was analyzed by cell sorting. Data represent means ± SEM of 3 independent experiments. In each experiment, 30,000 cells of 4 independently stressed cultures were measured using flow cytometry. ***p < 0.001, **p < 0.01. (G) Wild-type cells were treated with acetic acid and hydrogen peroxide and equal amounts of cells were harvested at the indicated time points, lysed, and the levels of Nde1 analyzed by western blotting. Ilv5 served as a loading control. (H) Wild-type cells were incubated with 0.4 mg/mL cycloheximide during the treatment without or with acetic acid and analyzed as in (G). (I) Model for the proapoptotic effect of the cytosol-exposed Nde1 topomer.

was functional as NADH dehydrogenase but not toxic. Thus, the toxic potential of Nde1 is obviously not just an unavoidable side effect of this class of enzymes but rather a distinct feature that serves a physiological function.

The distribution of Nde1 depends on mitochondrial import efficiency, which is influenced by the membrane potential and hence the functional state of the respiratory chain. Loss of mitochondrial DNA and other severe defects in oxidative phosphorylation reduce the membrane potential even under fermentative conditions, leading to a relative enrichment of the cytosolexposed Nde1 topomer. Nde1 is targeted to mitochondria by a bipartite targeting signal. Recent studies showed that proteins with such signals are particularly susceptible to stalling during translocation, especially upon mitochondrial damage (Boos et al., 2019; Må rtensson et al., 2019; Weidberg and Amon, 2018) .

Several mitochondrial proteins with dual localization have previously been described. The first example of a dually localized protein studied in detail was fumarase, a fraction of which stalls during translocation due to tight folding of its C-terminal domain and retro-translocates into the cytosol (Knox et al., 1998) . Cells with poorly energized mitochondria contain higher levels of cytosolic fumarase, similar to what we observed for Nde1.

A recent study identified the lipid transfer protein STARD7 as a dually localized protein. STARD7 is synthesized with a bipartite presequence, which targets the protein to the mitochondrial inner membrane. There, a fraction is cleaved by the rhomboid protease PARL (presenilins-associated rhomboid-like protein), thereby releasing a large functionally active fragment into the cytosol (Saita et al., 2018) . Another well-characterized example of a dually localized protein is PINK1 (PTENinduced kinase 1), which accumulates on the surface of poorly energized mitochondria, priming them for destruction by mitophagy (Narendra et al., 2010; Pickrell et al., 2015; Sekine et al., 2019) .

Comparably to the situation for STARD7 and PINK1, the formation of the cytosol-exposed isoform of Nde1 is favored by mitochondrial defects and the degradation of Nde1, and its fragments are mediated by both mitochondrial (Yme1) and cytosolic (proteasome/Cdc48/Doa1) proteolytic machineries. Hence, the functional state of the mitochondrial respiratory chain and of the major protein quality control systems together determine the intracellular distribution and hence the apoptotic potential of Nde1. Thereby, Nde1 appears to be part of a mechanism that continuously monitors the cellular state of both metabolism and proteostasis ( Figure 7E ). The pro-apoptotic potential of Nde1 is particularly pronounced upon metabolic stress conditions such as during temporary exposure to acetic acid or hydrogen peroxide. In this context, Nde1 serves as an essential mediator in metabolic signaling on the mitochondrial surface that has the potential to trigger programmed cell death. How cell death is executed by Nde1 is not known, but we observed a characteristic cytosolic fragment upon pro-apoptotic stimuli. Earlier studies reported that Nde1 can release deleterious amounts of hydrogen peroxide (Gomes et al., 2013) that might partly explain its toxic potential. However, we also observed toxicity for Nde1 mutants with much lower oxidoreductase activity and during anaerobic growth where hydrogen peroxide production seems unlikely. Unbiased genetic screening already identified the proteasome and the mitochondrial import motor as critical for the toxicity of Nde1. Hence, our results lay the basis for systematic investigations, employing the power of yeast genetics to characterize the downstream pathway of Nde1-mediated apoptosis.

Nde1 is a homolog of the mammalian AIF (Susin et al., 1999) . How comparable is Nde1-mediated apoptosis with the cell death program executed by AIF? There are actually many obvious similarities: (1) AIF and Nde1 can both function as NADH:ubiquinone oxidoreductases (Elguindy and Nakamaru-Ogiso, 2015); (2) AIF and Nde1 both reside in the IMS of mitochondria and a fraction of both proteins exposes a soluble domain to the cytosol (Yu et al., 2009) ; (3) AIF is under proteolytic control of proteases in the IMS (calpain) and of the proteasome in the cytosol (Liu et al., 2010; Norberg et al., 2010; Wilkinson et al., 2008) , very similar to the situation we found for Nde1; (4) AIF triggers cell death when respiratory enzyme activity is impaired (Klein et al., 2002; Wu et al., 2007) , exactly as we observed for Nde1-mediated toxicity; (5) cell death is induced by a characteristic AIF fragment that distributes throughout the cytosol and the nucleus (Joza et al., 2001; Polster et al., 2005) , similar to the Nde1 fragment observed in our study; (6) the toxic potential of AIF does not require its oxidoreductase activity (Loeffler et al., 2001) , just like that of Nde1; and (7) cells of mice lacking AIF are hyper-resistant to hydrogen peroxide (Chen et al., 2014) , just as we observed for Dnde1 yeast cells. Thus, the principles of Nde1/AIF-mediated cell death are conserved from yeast to humans. It appears likely that this specific cell death program is also employed in humans to prevent the propagation of respiration-deficient cells. Little is known about the downstream effects of AIF and how it executes cell death. We found that Cdc48, the yeast homolog of the mammalian VCP/p97, plays a critical role in the proteolytic control of Nde1. Actually, apoptosis in yeast was initially discovered by studies on cdc48 mutants (Madeo et al., 1997) , potentially due to their stabilizing effects on Nde1. It will be extremely exciting to use the power of yeast genetics to elucidate the components of the apoptotic pathway downstream of Nde1/AIF and to further define the physiological relevance of this system to maintain the respiration-competence of cell populations.

Yeast strains, plasmids and growth conditions The yeast strains used in this study are based on BY4742 background. BY4742 WT, Dnde1, Doxa1, Dpdr5 strains were obtained from Euroscarf. Dnde2 single and Dnde1Dnde2 double deletions were generated in WT and Dnde1 backgrounds by replacement of NDE2 genomic reading frame with a spHIS5 (Janke et al., 2004) . To select for positive colonies, yeast transformants were plated on a selective synthetic histidine dropout medium. The colonies for nde2 knockouts were verified by PCR. Dndi1 strain was generated by replacement of NDI1 genomic reading frame with a hphB cassette. To screen for positive colonies, transformants were plated on YPD medium containing hygromycin (300 mg/ml) and the deletion was further verified by PCR. For construction of the GAL-NDE1 strain harboring a chromosomal copy of NDE1 under GAL10 promoter, a cassette containing a HIS3 marker and a GAL10 promoter was amplified by PCR from the vector pTL26 (Lafontaine and Tollervey, 1996) and inserted into the yeast genome upstream of the NDE1 open reading frame. To select for positive colonies, yeast transformants were plated on a selective synthetic histidine dropout medium and further verified by PCR. Strain lacking mtDNA (rho 0 ) was generated by treatment of the wild-type strain (BY4742) with ethidium bromide (EtBr). Briefly, EtBr was added to a concentration of 10 mg/ml and the cells were incubated at 30 C, for approximately 24 h in YPD (1% yeast extract, 2% peptone, 2% dextrose). This is followed by another two rounds of treatment with 10 mg/ml EtBr for 24 h each. Following incubation with EtBr, the cells were diluted in water and plated on YPD to obtain single colonies. The rho 0 cells were selected as cells unable to grow on YPG (1% yeast extract, 2% peptone, 2% glycerol) plates, but can grow on YPD. In rho 0 cells the loss of mtDNA was verified by 4,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole DAPI (4,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole) staining. For complementation assays, the Su9 presequence of the plasmid pYX122-mtGFP (Westermann and Neupert, 2000) was replaced by the coding sequence for Nde1 with or without stop codon using the restriction sites EcoRI and BamHI, resulting in the expression of Nde1 or a Nde1-GFP fusion protein. The Nde1 mutations at the NAD binding site were generated by PCR-based site-directed mutagenesis (Quick-Change method, Stratagene) using suitable primer sequences with desired mutation. After successful mutagenesis Nde1 mutants were subcloned into pYX122-mtGFP as described for Nde1. In order to express Nde1 under its own promoter, a sequence ranging from 282 bp upstream of the start codon until 197 bp downstream of the stop codon of the NDE1 open reading frame were cloned into the vector pRS423 using BamHI and SalI restriction enzymes (Sikorski and Hieter, 1989) . To generate the constructs expressing the NADH binding domain of Nde1 without or with different mitochondrial presequences, a sequence corresponding to the residues 92 to 560 of Nde1 either with or without a start codon were amplified. The resulting sequences were cloned into the BamH1 and SalI sites of a pYX122 plasmid. The plasmid was opened with EcoRI and BamH1 and sequences corresponding to either the targeting regions of Tom70 (res. 1-36), Mia40 (res. 1-70), cytochrome b D19 (res. 1-148) were inserted respectively. The resulting DNA products code for the NADH binding domain of Nde1 without or with these different presequences. They were further subcloned into EcoRI/SalI sites of the p426Gal vector, resulting in the expression of these N-terminal Nde1 fusion proteins under the GAL1 promoter. Different C-terminal truncation mutants were also constructed and cloned into the p426Gal vector to have their expression under GAL1 promoter. Full-length Nde1 was amplified and cloned into p426Gal vector using EcoRI and SalI restriction sites. Truncation mutants of Nde1 were made by amplifying Nde1 with the same forward primer as for the full length and a series of reverse primers containing a SalI recognition site with a stop codon that amplifies from residue one to each selected position on the C terminus (residues 194, 364, 429, 500, and 548) , thereby truncating the C terminus. Then these C-terminal truncations were cloned into EcoRI/SalI sites of the p426Gal vector. Yeast transformation was carried out by the lithium acetate method (Gietz et al., 1992) . Empty vectors were also transformed in parallel to serve as negative controls. For galactose induced expression of p426Gal constructs, the cultures were switched from glucose containing medium to galactose containing medium and grown for another 16 h.

Yeast strains were either grown in YP (1% yeast extract, 2% peptone) or synthetic media containing 2% of glucose, galactose, glycerol at 30 C with agitation. To inactivate Cdc48 in the temperature-sensitive cdc48-2 strain, the culture was shifted from C to 37 C for 4 h, together with the corresponding wild-type. To express proteins from GAL promoters, cells were shifted to galactose containing medium for 16 h. For anaerobic growth, plates were incubated in a deoxygenated chamber with an oxygen cleansing catalyst and an anaerobic indicator.

Growth assays and viability tests For spot analysis, the respective yeast strains were grown in liquid rich or synthetic media. Total yeast cells equivalent to 1.0 OD at A600 were harvested at exponential phase. The cells were re-suspended in sterile water and subjected to treatment of apoptotic triggers, either 1.5 mM H 2 O 2 or 100 mM acetic acid followed by incubation for 3 h at 30 C. Subsequently, the cells were washed in sterile water and subjected to ten-fold serial dilutions. Each dilution was spotted on rich or synthetic media followed by incubation at 30 C. Pictures were taken after different days of the growth.

Growth curves were performed in a 96 well plate, using the automated ELx808 Absorbance Microplate Reader (BioTekÒ). The growth curves started at 0.1 OD at A600 and the OD at A600 was measured every 10 min for 72 h at 30 C. The mean of technical triplicates was calculated and plotted in R.

For viability tests, yeast strains were grown in galactose containing rich medium (YPGal) until they reach the exponential phase. The cells were harvested, added increasing concentrations of acetic acid and treated for 3 h to induce apoptosis. After the treatment, cells were washed and equal number of cells were plated on YPGal plates. Then counted the number of colonies that grew on the plates.

Yeast strains were grown in minimal media containing 2% of glucose. Total yeast cells equivalent to 1.0 OD at A600 were harvested at exponential phase and subjected to treatment of 100 mM acetic acid to induce apoptosis, for 30 min at 30 C. To determine the fraction of dead cells after acetic acid stress, cells were stained with propidium iodide (PI) and Annexin V. Therefore, $6x10 5 cells were stained in 96 well plates for 5 min with PI and Annexin V in PBS. Flow cytometry was performed using LSRII Fortessa equipped with a 96-well high-throughput sampler. For each sample at least 30,000 cells were analyzed.

To generate an antibody recognizing Nde1, the sequence corresponding to residues 104 to 561 was cloned into the expression plasmid pET-19b using NdeI and BamHI restriction sites resulting in a fragment with N-terminal His 6 -tagged Nde1. This recombinant protein was expressed in E. coli BL-21(DE3) cells at 30 C. Once growth reached an A600 value of 0.5 to 0.7, the cells were subjected to induction by 1 mM IPTG for 4 h. Cells were harvested by centrifugation and lysed in buffer-B (100 mM NaH 2 PO 4, 8 M urea, 10 mM Tris pH 8.0). The cell lysates were clarified by centrifugation at 10,000 x g for 30 min and the supernatant was incubated with Ni +2 -NTA Sepharose (GE Healthcare) for 1 h at 4 C. Unbound proteins and nonspecific contaminants were removed by sequential single washes with buffer C (100 mM NaH 2 PO 4, 8 M urea, 10 mM Tris pH 6.3) at 2,000 x g for 2 min. Finally, the bound proteins were eluted using buffer E (0.1% SDS, 200 mM imidazole, 20 mM Tris pH 7.4). The purified protein was used to raise antibodies in rabbits.

For isolation of mitochondria, yeast cells (OD 600 of 0.7-1.7) were harvested, washed with water and re-suspended in MP1 buffer (10 mM DTT, 100 mM Tris pH unadjusted) (2 ml/g wet weight). Cells were incubated for 10 min at 30 C at 160 rpm, pelleted (5 min at 4,000 x g at RT) and washed with 100 mL of 1.2 M sorbitol. Sedimented cells (5 min at 4,000 x g at RT) were lysed in MP2 buffer (1.2 M sorbitol, 20 mM KH PO 4 pH 7.4) (6.7 ml/g wet weight) supplemented with 3 mg zymolyase/g wet weight (Seikagaku Corporation) for 1 h at 30 C at 160 rpm. The spheroplasts generated during this process were harvested (5 min at 3,500 x g at 4 C), re-suspended in ice-cold homogenization buffer (0.6 M sorbitol, 1 mM EDTA pH 8, 1 mM phenylmethanesulfonyl fluoride (PMSF), 10 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.4, 0.2% fatty acid-free BSA) (13.4 ml/g wet weight) and dounced 10 times in a cooled potter homogenizer. The homogenate was centrifuged for 5 min at 3,500 x g at 4 C to separate cell debris and nuclei from organelles. The mitochondrial fraction was isolated by centrifugation of the supernatant from the previous step for 12 min at 12,000 x g at 2 C. The crude mitochondrial pellet was gently resuspended in 5 mL of SEH buffer (0.6 M sorbitol, 1 mM EDTA pH 8, 20 mM HEPES/KOH pH 7.4), centrifuged for 5 min at 4,000 x g at 4 C, recovered from the supernatant by centrifugation for 12 min at 12,000 x g at 2 C and finally resuspended in 0.2-1 mL SH buffer (0.6 M sorbitol, 20 mM HEPES/KOH pH 7.4). The protein concentration of the mitochondrial suspension was determined by Bradford assay (Bradford, 1976) . Then, mitochondria were diluted to a final concentration of 10 mg/ml protein with ice-cold SH buffer, aliquoted, frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at À80 C.

Rate of oxygen consumption of isolated mitochondria was measured polarographically using a Clark-type oxygen electrode connected to a computer-operated Oxygraph control unit (Hansatech Instruments, Germany) at 25 C. The rate was measured by addition of 100 mg of isolated mitochondria resuspended in a respiration medium containing 0.6 M sorbitol, 20 mM HEPES/KOH (pH 7.4) and 1 mM MgCl 2 to the oxygraph chamber and with continuous stirring. Respiration was initiated with the additions of 7 mM NADH and recorded at sampling intervals of 1 s (Oxygraph Plus software, Hansatech Instruments).

Protein import into isolated mitochondria Precursor proteins were radiolabelled with 35 S-methionine using the TNTÒ Quick Coupled Transcription/Translation kit (Promega). The import of radiolabeled precursor proteins into isolated mitochondria of S. cerevisiae was performed as described (Mesecke et al., 2005) . Briefly, 50 mg of isolated mitochondria were mixed with the import buffer (1 M sorbitol, 100 mM HEPES/KOH pH 7.4, 160 mM KCl, 20 mM Mg(OAc) 2 , 4 mM KH 2 PO 4 ). In addition, 2 mM ATP and 2 mM NADH were supplied to energize mitochondria. Import reactions were started by addition of radiolabeled precursor, proceeded at 30 C and stopped at different time points by tenfold dilution of the import mixture in ice-cold SH (0.6 M sorbitol, 20 mM HEPES/KOH pH 7.4) buffer. Non-imported material was removed by incubation of samples for 30 min with 100 mg/ml protease (proteinase K, Applichem) on ice. Protease treatment was stopped by addition of 2 mM PMSF. Next, mitochondria were re-isolated by centrifugation for 10 min at 20,000 x g at 4 C, washed once with SHKCl buffer (0.6 M sorbitol, 20 mM HEPES/KOH pH 7.4, 150 mM KCl) supplemented with 2 mM PMSF and re-suspended in sample buffer. Samples were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and signals of radiolabeled proteins were detected by autoradiography on Biomax MR-1 films (Kodak, Rochester, NY).

Swelling and proteinase K treatment of mitochondria 100 mg of mitochondria were resuspended either in isotonic buffer (in the import buffer containing 1 M sorbitol, 100 mM HEPES/KOH pH 7.4, 160 mM KCl, 20 mM magnesium acetate, 4 mM KH 2 PO 4 ) or hypotonic buffer (20 mM HEPES pH 7.6) and incubated on ice for 20 minutes without or with 100 mg/ml proteinase K. After 20 min incubation, proteinase K was inactivated by the addition of mM PMSF and mitochondria were re-isolated by centrifugation at 20,000 x g at 4 C for 10 minutes. The mitochondria were washed once with import buffer supplemented with mM PMSF, pelleted by centrifugation and resuspended in sample buffer. Samples were analyzed by SDS-PAGE, followed by western blot analysis.

Cellular localization of Nde1-GFP fusion protein was analyzed by fluorescence microscopy using Leica Fluorescence Microscope with 63 x oil objective lens. Dnde1 cells co-expressing Nde1-GFP and MTS-RFP were inoculated and grown at 30 C till log phase (A600 $0.8). Then the cells were washed once with sterile water and subsequently fixed on microscopic slides for fluorescence imaging analysis. mtRFP specifically stains mitochondria.

Biotinylation of mitochondrial surface exposed proteins Surface proteins of isolated mitochondria from S. cerevisiae were biotinylated using procedures similar to those in a previous publication (Voss et al., 2014) , with some modifications. Briefly, 250 ug of isolated mitochondria were washed once with SH buffer (0.6 M sorbitol, 20 mM HEPES/KOH pH7.4) 12,000 3 g for 20 min at 4 C. Resuspended the mitochondria in SH buffer containing 1 ml of 0.2 mg/ml sulfo-NHS-SS-biotin (dissolves in DMSO) and incubated for 10 min or 30 min at 4 C on a shaker. The reaction was quenched by the addition of two volumes of 10 mM glycine in SH buffer, washed for two times, and resuspended in 1 x RIPA lysis buffer (150 mM NaCl, 1% NP-40, 0.5% deoxycholate, 5 mM EDTA pH 8, 0.1% SDS and 100 mM PMSF, 20 mM Tris pH 7.4). Mitochondria were incubated for 30 min at 4 C on a shaker and then pelleted at 12,000 3 g for 20 min at 4 C. 10% of the supernatant (corresponding to the total input) was taken as an input control. The remaining supernatant was incubated with 50 ml of equilibrated streptavidin agarose slurry overnight and centrifuged at 2,000 3 g for 2 min at 4 C. 10% of supernatant (corresponding to nonbiotinylated fraction) was taken as a non-biotinylated protein control and removed the remaining supernatant. The beads were washed three times in RIPA buffer and eluted the biotinylated protein fractions with the sample buffer. The control sample was processed in parallel using exactly the same procedures, except that sulfo-NHS-SS-biotin was omitted from the labeling reaction. Protein fractions were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and autoradiography for marker proteins.

Yeast cells (OD 600 of 0.7-1.7) were harvested at 700 3 g for 7 min at RT and re-suspended in SP1 buffer (10 mM DTT, 100 mM Tris pH unadjusted). Cells were incubated for 10 min at 30 C at 160 rpm. Pelleted cells (5 min at 1,000 x g at RT) were lysed in 6 mL of SP2 buffer (0.6 M sorbitol, 1X YP, 0.2% Glucose, 50 mM potassium phosphate pH 7.4, 3 mg zymolase/g wet weight) for 1 h at 30 C at 160 rpm. The spheroplasts generated during this process were harvested (5 min at 1,000 x g at RT), re-suspended in SP3 buffer (1 x YP, 1% glucose, 0.7 M sorbitol) and incubated for 20 min at 30 C at 160 rpm. Spheroplasts were collected by centrifuging at 1,000 x g, 4 C for 5 min, washed two times with ice cold SEM buffer (250 mM sucrose, 1 mM EDTA, 10 mM MOPS-KOH, pH 7.2, 2 mM PMSF) and dounced 15 times in a cooled potter homogenizer. The protein concentration of the spheroplast suspension was determined by Bradford assay. Then, the spheroplasts suspension was layered on 15 to 80% sucrose gradient prepared in EM buffer (1 mM EDTA, 10 mM MOPS-KOH, pH 7.2). This was followed by centrifugation for 1 h at 38,000 x g in a SW 41 rotor at 4 C. The fractions of 1 mL were collected, analyzed by SDS-PAGE and autoradiography for several marker proteins.
body_text.section: Isolation of spheroplasts and sucrose density gradient centrifugation

body_text.text: To analyze proteasome-dependent degradation, log phase cultures were supplemented with 100 mM of MG132 or DMSO for 1 h, at 30 C before the addition of 0.4 mg/ml cycloheximide. Cells were harvested at the times indicated and resuspended in lysis buffer (50 mM HEPES/KOH pH 7.5, 5 mM EDTA pH 8, 150 mM NaCl, 1% Triton X-100, 2 mM PMSF). After adding the glass beads (0.5 mm), cells were lysed by three rounds of bead beating (40 s beating followed by 1 min cooling on ice). Equal protein amounts were subjected to SDS-PAGE and western blotting.

For whole cell lysates, yeast strains were cultured either in rich or selective media and an OD 2 was harvested in their exponential growth phase. Cells were washed with water and resuspended in reducing loading buffer and added glass beads (0.5 mm). Cells were lysed by three rounds of bead beating (40 s beating followed by 1 min cooling on ice) using FastPrep-24 5G from MP Biomedicals. Lysates were boiled at 96 C for 5 min. The equal amount of 0.2 up to 0.4 OD at A600 was loaded on the SDS-gel.

A yeast culture of an arginine and lysine auxotroph yeast strain (YPH499 Darg4) was cultured in synthetic minimal medium containing 2% lactate as carbon source and ''light'' isotopes of arginine (Arg0, 12 C 6 / 14 N 4 ) and lysine (Lys0, 12 C 6 / 14 N 2 ). In mid-log phase (OD 600 $0.6), the medium was removed by centrifugation (5 min, 5,000 g), cells were washed once in medium not containing any arginine or lysine and then resuspended with medium containing ''heavy'' arginine (Arg10, 13 C 6 / 15 N 4 ) and lysine (Lys8, 13 C 6 / 15 N 2 ). Samples of $50 OD 600 *ml were drawn before (0 h) and after (0.75 h, 1.5 h, 3 h, 4.5 h, 6 h and 12 h for the time course, 4.5 h for the independent replication) medium shift by centrifugation (5 min, 5,000 g), immediately snap frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at À80 C until further processing. Growth of the culture was measured as OD at each time point of harvesting. Mitochondria were isolated as described above, but the final pellet was resuspended in 20 mM HEPES/KOH pH 7.4 instead of SH buffer.
body_text.section: Dynamic isotope labeling of mitochondrial proteins

body_text.text: Mass spectrometry sample preparation and analysis was performed basically as described by Hammel et al. (2018) with minor modifications. In brief, proteins were digested in solution and desalted on home made STAGE tips. For peptide LC-MS/MS analysis, a nano-LC 425 HPLC coupled to a TripleTOF 6600 mass spectrometer (Eksigent and ABSciex) was employed, but using a longer (68 min) gradient for separation. Data were acquired using one MS survey scan (350 -1400 m/z, 250 ms accumulation time) triggering MS/MS scans (100 -1500 m/z, 50 ms accumulation time, rolling collision energy) on the most intense precursors with an intensity > 300 cps resulting in a 1.8 s cycle time. After MS/MS analysis, the selected precursors were excluded for 12 s from analysis.

Peptide and protein identification and quantification was done using the MaxQuant software (version 1.5.8.3) (Cox and Mann, 2008; Cox et al., 2011; Tyanova et al., 2016) and Saccharomyces genome database (SGD, http://www.yeastgenome.org) (yeast orf trans all, 03-Feb-2011). For heavy labels Arg10 and Lys8 was chosen, up to 2 tryptic miss-cleavages were allowed, protein N-terminal acetylation and Met oxidation were specified as variable modifications and Cys carbamidomethylation as fixed modification. The ''match between runs,'' ''Requantify'' and ''Second Peptides'' options were selected. False discovery rate was set at 1% for peptides, proteins and sites, minimal peptide length was 7 amino acids.

The identified proteins were filtered to remove non-mitochondrial contaminants using the yeast mitochondrial reference proteome from Morgenstern et al. (2017) . From the heavy-over-light ratios r i for protein i, the proportion of heavy protein (as proxy of newly synthesized protein) was calculated as r i / (r i + 1).

To introduce the Gal10pr-NDE1-natMX sequence to the yeast deletion collection the Synthetic Genetic Array (SGA) technique (Tong et al., 2001 ) was used. The SGA technique allows efficient introduction of a trait (mutation or marker) into systematic yeast libraries. A query strain was generated by integrating the Gal10pr-NDE1 into the NDE1 locus of a MATalpha SGA-ready strain (YMS721). Two libraries were utilized: the yeast deletion collection (Giaever et al., 2002) together with the DAmP hypomorphic allele library (Breslow et al., 2008) . SGA was performed as previously described (Cohen and Schuldiner, 2011) . Briefly: using a RoToR benchtop colony arrayer (Singer Instruments, UK) to manipulate libraries in high-density formats (384 or 1536), haploid strains from opposing mating types, each harboring a different genomic alteration, were mated on rich media plates. Diploid cells were selected on plates containing all selection markers found on both parent haploid strains. Sporulation was then induced by transferring cells to nitrogen starvation plates. Haploid cells containing all desired mutations were selected for by transferring cells to plates containing all selection markers alongside the toxic amino acid derivatives canavanine and thialysine to select against remaining diploids. The new yeast libraries, in which each colony harbored the Gal10pr-NDE1 locus on the genetic background of a single mutation, were spotted on synthetic medium with 2% glucose as control or on medium containing 3% galactose (to induce the transgene) and with addition of 50 mM acetic acid to induce apoptosis. Strains were grown for 96 hours at 30 C and then imaged. Colony size was then quantified using the Balony free software for the analysis of images of plates containing arrays of yeast (software package is maintained by Barry Young at the University of British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada) (Young and Loewen, 2013) .
body_text.section: Screen for suppressors of Nde1 overexpression toxicity

body_text.text: Cultures were grown to mid log phase (OD 0.6 -0.8) under non-inducing conditions and shifted to inducing conditions by addition of 0.5% galactose. 2 OD 600 of cells were harvested by centrifugation (17,000 g, 3 min, C) before 90 min after induction, washed with prechilled water, snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at À80 C. Cells lysates were prepared in lysis buffer (50 mM Tris pH 7.0, 130 mM NaCl, 5 mM EDTA, 5% (w/v) SDS) using a FastPrep-24 5G homogenizer (MP Biomedicals, Heidelberg, Germany) with 3 cycles of 20 s, speed 6.0 m/s, 120 s breaks, lysis matrix Y). RNA was extracted from lysates using the phenol-chloroform method essentially as described (Schmitt et al., 1990) . Briefly, RNA was purified with repeated extraction with phenol-chloroform-isoamylalcohol (25:24:1, three times) and chloroform-isoamylalcohol (24:1, two times), brought to 0.3 M sodium acetate (pH 5.5), precipitated with ethanol and resuspended in water. DNA was removed with the Turbo DNA free kit (Ambion). cDNA was prepared from 500 ng total RNA using the qScript cDNA Synthesis Kit (Quanta Biosciences). RNA and cDNA quality and concentration were assessed with a NanoDrop fluorometer (ThermoFisher).

Quantitative real-time PCR assays qPCR reactions were performed using a CFX96 Touch Real-Time PCR Detection System (BioRad) in technical triplicates. DNA was PCR-amplified under the following conditions: 3 min at 95 C followed by 44 cycles of 10 s at 95 C, 30 s at 62 C and 30 s at 60 C. For all PCRs, iQ SYBR Green Supermix (Biorad) was used in the reaction. For normalization, TFC1 was selected as housekeeping gene based on published observations (Teste et al., 2009) . Standard curves for primer efficiency were generated by serial dilution of pooled cDNA. Only primer pairs with efficiency between 90% and 110% were used.

The 2 -DDCt method (Livak and Schmittgen, 2001 ) was used for data analysis, normalizing the gene expression values to the transcript levels of the housekeeping gene and to the empty vector control as reference condition.

Films were scanned and processed in Coral Photopaint X7 and figures assessed in Coral Draw X7. Quantifications were done using the Multi Guage software. Microscopy pictures were processed in Fiji and figures assessed in Coral Draw X7. Statistical analysis was performed in Excel 2016 to determine the mean, standard deviation or standard error. Graphs were either assessed using R or Excel 2016. Two-tailed Student's t test was used for comparison and the differences were considered significant at p < 0.05. ***p < 0.001, **p < 0.01.
The mass spectrometry proteomics data have been deposited to the ProteomeXchange Consortium via the PRIDE (Perez-Riverol et al., 2019) partner repository with the dataset identifier PRIDE: PXD012531.

FIGREF0.text: Nde1 Is an Exceptionally Unstable Mitochondrial Protein

FIGREF1.text: Nde1 Exhibits Two Different Activities (A) Structures of the three related NADH dehydrogenases Nde1, Nde2, and Ndi1. (B)

FIGREF2.text: Nde1 Forms Two Distinct Topomers in Mitochondria

FIGREF3.text: Figure 4. The Two Nde1 Topomers Are Formed during the Import of the Protein

FIGREF4.text: Nde1 Is under Control of Two Proteolytic Systems (A) Whole cell extracts and mitochondria of the indicated strains were analyzed by western blotting. Tom70 or Ilv5 and Sod1 served as controls for mitochondrial and cytosolic proteins, respectively.

FIGREF5.text: (H) Different amounts of wild-type and Dyme1 mitochondria were analyzed by western blotting. The characteristic $20-22 kDa fragment observed in Dyme1 mitochondria is indicated by an arrow (f mito ). (I) Schematic illustration of Nde1 degradation by cellular proteases.

FIGREF6.text: Nde1 Is a Proapoptotic Factor(A) Phylogenetic tree of NADH dehydrogenases of yeast, plant, mouse, and human mitochondria.

FIGREF7.text: Nde1 Counterselects against Respiration-Deficient Cells(A) The indicated strains were transformed with empty or Nde1 overexpression plasmids. Cells were isolated from galactose-grown cultures, lysed, and analyzed by western blotting. The position of the cytosolic f cyto fragment is indicated by an arrowhead. (B) Cells were incubated in the presence of 80 mM acetic acid for 2 h, washed, diluted serially, and dropped onto glucose-containing medium to monitor the number of surviving cells. (C) Equal numbers of cells of the indicated strains were dropped on glucose plates. Note that the absence of Nde1 leads to a much higher viability in respiration-deficient petite cells, indicated with arrowheads. On the right, blow-ups are shown for better visibility of petite colonies. Mean and SD from n = 3 independent biological replicates are shown. (D) Cells of the indicated strains were grown in galactose-containing medium, and DNA was stained with DAPI and analyzed by fluorescent microscopy to visualize nuclear and mitochondrial DNA. (E) Model for the proapoptotic role of Nde1. See text for details.

M. Schuldiner is an incumbent of the Dr. Gilbert Omenn and Martha Darling Professorial Chair in Molecular Genetics. AUTHOR CONTRIBUTIONS S.S. and F.B. designed, cloned, and verified the constructs and strains. J.M.H. conceived the project. S.S. and F.B characterized the role of Nde1 in metabolism and cellular fitness. M.P. and F.M. characterized the pro-apoptotic activity of Nde1. F.B. designed and carried out the dynamic SILAC labeling strategy. F.S. and M. Schroda analyzed the mitochondrial proteome by mass spectrometry. F.B. and T.M. performed the bioinformatical analysis of the mass spectrometry data. S.S., H.M., and M. Schuldiner designed and performed genetic screens to identify Nde1-resistant yeast mutants. S.S., F.B., M.P., H.M., M. Schuldiner and J.M.H. analyzed the data. F.B. and J.M.H. wrote the manuscript.
